facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 270 of 1963 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 7, 1959 of the Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 184 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 270 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 7, 1959 of the Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 184 of 1956.

facts.text: Plaintiff-appellant instituted a suit on April 19, 1951 in the Court of the Second Joint Civil Judge, Junior Division at Bagalkot for possession of suit properties on redemption of a mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: On April 19, 1951, the plaintiff-appellant instituted a suit in the Court of the Second Joint Civil Judge, Junior Division at Bagalkot, for possession of the suit properties on redemption of a mortgage and the taking of accounts on the allegation that defendant No. 1 was the usufructuary mortgagee under a mortgage deed dated June 28, 1945  Ex. 43 .

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 was the usufructuary mortgagee under mortgage deed dated June 28, 1945 Ex. 43.

anchor.surface_text: On April 19, 1951, the plaintiff-appellant instituted a suit in the Court of the Second Joint Civil Judge, Junior Division at Bagalkot, for possession of the suit properties on redemption of a mortgage and the taking of accounts on the allegation that defendant No. 1 was the usufructuary mortgagee under a mortgage deed dated June 28, 1945  Ex. 43 .

facts.text: Defendants pleaded that the transaction of June 28, 1945 was an advance lease and not a mortgage, and they were protected tenants under the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants pleaded that the transaction of June 28, 1945 was an advance lease and number a mortgage, and they were protected tenants within the meaning of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948  Bombay Act LXVII of 1948  hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Trial Court passed decree on March 4, 1953 holding that deed Exhibit 43 is a composite document comprising mortgage and lease, mortgage debt fully redeemed, plaintiff to seek remedy in Revenue Courts.

anchor.surface_text: On March 4, 1953, the trial Court passed the following decree 10.  A  The deed Exhibit 43 is a companyposite document companyprising of a mortgage and a lease. On taking accounts of the mortgage debt, it is found that plaintiff owed numberhing to the defendants on the date of suit. The mortgage stands fully redeemed. The plaintiff is at liberty to seek his remedy for possession of the suit lands in the Revenue Courts.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed appeal on April 15, 1953 in the Court of the Assistant Judge at Bijapur, defendants filed cross-objections.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff shall recover half the companyts of the suit from the defendants and the defendants shall bear their own. On April 15, 1953, the plaintiff filed an appeal in the Court of the Assistant Judge at Bijapur, and the defendants filed crossobjections.

facts.text: First appellate Court on July 5, 1955 held Civil Court has no jurisdiction to determine if defendant No. 1 was mortgagee or tenant, confirmed no debt due, remanded to trial court to refer to Tenancy Court.

anchor.surface_text: On July 5, 1955, the first appellate Court held that the Civil Court had numberjurisdiction to determine whether defendant No. 1 was a mortgagee in possession or a tenant, and passed the following decree The appeal is partly allowed. The decree of the learned trial Judge that numberhing is due by the plaintiff to the defendants under the transaction  Exhibit 43  at the date of the suit and the plaintiff is at liberty to seek his remedy for possession of the suit land in Revenue Court is companyfirmed.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed second appeal on October 1, 1955 in the High Court of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1955, the plaintiff filed a second appeal in the High Court of Mysore.

facts.text: Mysore High Court on December 7, 1959 dismissed second appeal, held Civil Court no jurisdiction to interpret Ex.43, directed reference to Mamlatdar.

anchor.surface_text: On December 7, 1959, the High Court dismissed the second appeal. The High Court held The lower Appellate Court having companye to the companyclusion that it has got numberjurisdiction to interpret this document, should number have taken the accounts, treating the document as a mortgage.

facts.text: Plaintiff's petitions for review and leave to file Letters Patent Appeal dismissed on April 14, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent petitions by the plaintiff for review of this decree and for leave to file a Letters Patent Appeal were dismissed on April 14, 1960.

facts.text: Plaintiff appeals to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff number appeals to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Suit lands are agricultural lands within the meaning of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The suit lands are agricultural lands within the meaning of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948.

facts.text: Appellant contended Civil Court has jurisdiction based on plaint allegations for possession on redemption, Mamlatdar has no jurisdiction, should decide tenant issue itself.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. Patwardhan companytended that the jurisdiction of a Civil Court depends upon the allegations made in the plaint, the Civil Court has full jurisdiction to try a suit for recovery of possession of agricultural lands on redemption of a mortgage and the Mamlatdar has numberjurisdiction to try such a suit, the plea in the written statement that the defendants were protected tenants did number oust the jurisdiction of the Civil Court.

facts.text: Respondents contended High Court rightly referred issue to Mamlatdar.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents, Mr. Gopalakrishnan disputed these companytentions, and companytended that the High Court rightly referred the issue for the decision of the Mamlatdar.

facts.text: Trial court found plaintiff owed nothing to defendants on date of suit under mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: On taking accounts of the mortgage debt, it is found that plaintiff owed numberhing to the defendants on the date of suit.

facts.text: First appellate court confirmed nothing due under Ex.43 at date of suit.

anchor.surface_text: The decree of the learned trial Judge that numberhing is due by the plaintiff to the defendants under the transaction  Exhibit 43  at the date of the suit

facts.text: High Court set aside first appellate finding on accounts as Civil Court should not have taken accounts treating as mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The lower Appellate Court having companye to the companyclusion that it has got numberjurisdiction to interpret this document, should number have taken the accounts, treating the document as a mortgage. Therefore, I set aside that finding of the Assistant Judge.

facts.text: Section 85A introduced by Bombay Act XIII of 1956, came into force March 23, 1956 during pendency of second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Section 85A was introduced by Bombay Act XIII of 1956, which came into force on March 23, 1956 during the pendency of the second appeal in this case.

facts.text: Suit governed by law before introduction of s.85A.

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which this appeal arises was governed by the law as it stood before the introduction of s. 85A.

facts.text: Bombay High Court in Dhondi Tukarain v. Hari Dadu held Civil Court to refer tenant plea to Mamlatdar.

anchor.surface_text: But independently of s. 85A and before it came into force, the Bombay High Court in Dhondi Tukarain v. Hari Dadu 1  held that the effect of ss. 70 b  and 85 read in the light of the other provisions of the Act was that if in a suit filed against the defendant on the footing that he is a trespasser he raises the plea that he is a tenant or a protected tenant the Civil Court had numberjurisdiction to deal with the plea, and the proper procedure was to refer the issue to the Mamlatdar for his decision

facts.text: First appellate court recorded inconsistent findings.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellate Court recorded inconsistent findings.

holdings.text: In a suit for possession of agricultural land framed as against a mortgagee or trespasser, if defendant pleads he is a tenant, protected tenant or permanent tenant, Civil Court must refer the issue to Mamlatdar, stay suit, and dispose in light of Mamlatdar's decision.

anchor.surface_text: The Mamlatdar has no jurisdiction to try a suit by a landowner for recovery of possession of agricultural lands from a trespasser or from a mortgagee on redemption of a mortgage, and the Civil Court has jurisdiction to entertain such a suit but if the defendant to the suit pleads that he is a tenant or a protected tenant or a permanent tenant and an issue arises whether he is such a tenant, the Court must refer the issue to the Mamlatdar for determination, and must stay the suit pending such determination, and after the Mamlatdar has decided the issue, the Court may dispose of the suit in the light of the decision of the Mamlatdar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combined effect of ss.29,70,85,85A ousts Civil Court jurisdiction over tenancy issues; Mamlatdar exclusive for tenants, Civil Court refers when pleaded.

holdings.text: Independently of s.85A and under law before its enactment, courts bound to refer tenancy issue to Mamlatdar under ss.70(b) and 85 read with other provisions.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that independently of s. 85A and under the law as it stood before s. 85A came into force, the Courts below were bound to refer to the Mamlatdar the decision of the issue whether the defendant is a tenant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dhondi Tukaram correctly interpreted ss.70(b),85; approved by legislature via s.85A; Civil Court no jurisdiction over tenant plea even pre-85A.

holdings.text: Dhondi Tukaram v. Hari Dadu correctly interpreted the law as it stood before enactment of s.85A.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature approved via s.85A; resolves debate on s.70 scope; startling but correct result.

holdings.text: High Court had jurisdiction in second appeal to set aside first appellate court's finding that nothing due under Ex.43.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No substance; first appellate court recorded inconsistent findings after holding no jurisdiction to interpret document or take accounts.

anchor.surface_text: Dhondi Tukarain v. Hari Dadu 1

precedents.cited_proposition: effect of ss. 70 b and 85 read in the light of the other provisions of the Act was that if in a suit filed against the defendant on the footing that he is a trespasser he raises the plea that he is a tenant or a protected tenant the Civil Court had no jurisdiction to deal with the plea, and the proper procedure was to refer the issue to the Mamlatdar for his decision and not to dismiss the suit straightaway
precedents.cited_holding: Therefore, we hold that in a suit filed against the defendant on the footing that he is a trespasser if he raises the plea that he is a tenant or a protected tenant, the Civil Court would have no jurisdiction to deal with that plea. We would, however, like to add that in all such cases where the Civil Court cannot entertain the plea and accepts the objection that it has no jurisdiction to try it should not proceed to dismiss the suit straightaway.

precedents.cited_proposition: debatable point whether the expression for the purposes of this Act meant that the Mamlatdar had jurisdiction to decide those issues even though they arose for decision in a suit properly cognisable by a Civil Court

anchor.surface_text: Mudugere Rangaiah v. M. Rangaiah 2

precedents.cited_proposition: the jurisdiction of the Amildar is limited to cases arising by or under the Mysore Tenancy Act and the Civil Court had jurisdiction to decide all the points in dispute in the suit including the question of tenancy

anchor.surface_text: The Mamlatdar has no jurisdiction to try a suit by a landowner for recovery of possession of agricultural lands from a trespasser or from a mortgagee on redemption of a mortgage, and the Civil Court has jurisdiction to entertain such a suit but if the defendant to the suit pleads that he is a tenant or a protected tenant or a permanent tenant and an issue arises whether he is such a tenant, the Court must refer the issue to the Mamlatdar for determination, and must stay the suit pending such determination, and after the Mamlatdar has decided the issue, the Court may dispose of the suit in the light of the decision of the Mamlatdar.
